column4: Ontology Title: System OntologyI. System: A structured set of components or entities that interact in a defined way for a common purpose.        A. Components/Entities: Individual parts that make up a system.        1. Input: The data or resources that are entered into a system for processing.        2. Output: The result or output produced by a system after processing the input data.         3. Processes: The elements that carry out operations within a system, transforming inputs into outputs.     B. Types of Systems:        1. Physical Systems: A combination of physical components organized to perform a specific function.        2. Information Systems: Systems that handle the flow and storage of information in an organization.        3. Biological Systems: Systems that occur naturally in all types of living organisms.        4. Social Systems: Groups of individuals forming a complex whole, such as societies or families.        5. Computer Systems: Hardware and software components that work together to process data.II. Properties of Systems    A. Open System: A system that regularly interacts with its environment, taking inputs from it and giving outputs back.    B. Closed System: A system virtually isolated from its environment, exchanges very little to no matter or energy outside.        C. Isolated System: A theoretical concept where a system has no interactions with an external environment.III. System Characteristics    A. Efficiency: The degree to which inputs are well-used for their intended task.    B. Effectiveness: The degree to which a system achieves its intended goal.    C. Reliability: The consistency of a system in producing the same outcome under the same conditions.    D. Flexibility: The ability of a system to adapt to changes in its environment or in its inputs.    E. Resilience: The ability of a system to cope with unexpected disturbances or shocks.    IV. System Behaviors    A. Dynamic Behavior: The time-dependent behavior of a system in response to an external environment.    B. Static Behavior: The behavior of a system in response to constant or lack of external stimuli.    V. System Management    A. System Analysis: Identifying and clarifying problems or improvements in the system.    B. System Design: Developing a plan to solve the problem or incorporate improvements.    C. System Implementation: Introducing the new design into the existing system.     D. System Maintenance: Regular checks to ensure the longevity, efficiency, and productivity of the system. VI. System Lifecycle    A. Creation/Design/Development: The phase where the system is being planned and constructed.    B. Deployment/Implementation: The phase where the system begins to be used.    C. Operation/Production: The phase where the system is fully operational.    D. Maintenance: Regular checks and improvements of the system.    E. Retirement/Dismissal: The phase when the system is no longer in use.

column4: Ontology Concept: System1. Sub-concepts   i. Physical System: Describes systems relating to physical or tangible objects in the world. E.g. Solar system, Mechanical system.   ii. Biological System: It includes systems relating to the biological world. E.g. Human circulatory system, Ecosystem.   iii. Computational System: It includes systems used in computing. E.g. Operating system, Database management system.   iv. Social System: It relates to systems focusing on the organization of various social structures. E.g. Economic system, Political system.   v. Theoretical System: These are conceptual and non-material systems. E.g. Mathematical system, Linguistic system.2. Related Concepts   i. Components: The different parts making up a system.   ii. Interactions: The way components interact within the system.   iii. Environment: The setting in which a system exists.   iv. Sub-systems: Smaller systems within a larger system.   v. Supra-systems: Larger systems that a system is a part of.   3. Properties   i. System state: The current condition of the system at any time.   ii. Stability: A system's capacity to return to steady state after a disruption.   iii. Complexity: The level of components' diversity and their interactions.   iv. Adaptability: The system's ability to change and evolve.   v. Openness: The system's ability to interact with its environment.   4. Functions   i. Input: The material or energy that enters the system from the environment.   ii. Process: The manner in which the system manipulates the input.   iii. Output: The material or energy that leaves the system to the environment.   iv. Feedback: The system's process for utilizing the output information to modify the input or process for adjustment purposes.5. Attributes    i. Efficiency: The measure of output to input ratio in the system.    ii. Effectiveness: The degree to which the system's output matches its intended purpose.   iii. Resilience: The capacity of a system to absorb disturbances and reorganize to still perform essentially the same function.6. Classes of Systems   i. Closed Systems: These do not interact with their environment.   ii. Open Systems: These interact freely with their environment.   iii. Complex Systems: Systems with huge numbers of components and intricate interactions.   iv. Simple Systems: Systems with few components and less intricate interactions.7. Relationships   i. System-Component: Each system consists of components.   ii. System-Environment: Each system exists within a certain environment.   iii. Systems-Sub-systems: Each system may contain sub-systems and may be part of a supra-system.   iv. System-Processes: Each system has processes which manage inputs and create outputs.   v. Input-Output: Every system has input and output which often are interconnected through feedback.

Types:        - Input: Information or resources that the system takes in to process or change.        - Processor: The part of the system that changes or processes the input.        - Output: The result or product that comes out of the system as a result of the processing.         - Feedback: Information about the output that is used to adjust the input or the process. 3. **System Characteristics**    - Definition: These are the attributes or properties that a system exhibits.    - Types:        - Complexity: The degree to which a system's components interact and with varying degrees of reliance on each other.        - Robustness: The ability of a system to handle errors, failures, or changes without breaking down.        - Adaptability: The ability of a system to adjust or modify itself in response to changes in the environment or in its input.4. **System Types**    - Definition: The categories into which systems can be classified based on their components, characteristics, or functions.     - Types:        - Natural Systems: Systems that exist in nature, such as ecosystems or the human body.         - Artificial Systems: Systems created by human beings, such as computer systems or transportation systems.        - Closed Systems: Systems that do not interact with their environment.        - Open Systems: Systems that interact with their environment, exchanging information, material, or energy.        5. **System Functions**    - Definition: The roles or tasks that a system performs in order to achieve its purpose.     - Types:        - Data Processing: The function of transforming raw data into meaningful information.        - Control: The function of managing or directing the operation of the system.         - Communication: The function of exchanging information between different parts of the system or with the system's environment. 6. **System Design**    - Definition: The process of creating a system or planning how its components should be arranged and interact.    - Components:        - Blueprint: A detailed plan or scheme showing the structure of the system.        - Operation: The ongoing use and maintenance of the system.        - Retirement: The process of ending the system's operation and disposing of its components.

Types of Systems   A. Physical Systems: Systems existing in the physical world, such as the solar system or hydraulic system.      B. Biological Systems: Systems existing in the biological world, such as the human circulatory system or ecosystem.   C. Digital Systems: Systems existing in the digital technology field, such as computer systems or information systems.   D. Social Systems: Systems existing in society, such as social networks or economic systems.   E. Conceptual Systems: Abstract systems, such as mathematical systems, legal systems, or philosophical systems.III. Components of a System   A. Elements: Individual parts that make up a system. Each has its own properties.   B. Interrelationships: The connections between the elements of a system that influence one another.   C. Boundaries: Limits that define what is inside the system and what lies outside it. It separates the system from its environment.IV. System Properties   A. System Behavior: The functionality or actions that a system demonstrates.   B. System Structure: The arrangement and relation of interconnections between elements of the system.   C. System State: The conditions or attributes at any given point in time.V. System Functions    A. Input: The information or resources that the system takes in to attain its goal.        B. Process: The transformation of inputs to achieve the desired output.        C. Output: The result or product of the system processes.VI. System Environment   A. Context: The broader system in which a given system exists and operates.      B. Feedback: Information from within the system environment that is taken in and influences the system.VII. System Dynamics   A. Stabilization: The ability of a system to maintain a steady-state or equilibrium.      B. Change and Evolution: The process where a system undergoes modification or evolution over time. VIII. System Complexity   A. Simple Systems: Systems with few components having simple relationships.      B. Complex Systems: Systems with numerous interacting components having complex relationships, often showing emergent behavior.IX. System Lifecycles   A. Creation: The inception or establishment of a system.      B. Operation: The routine functioning of a system.      C. Termination: The end or discontinuation of a system.
